original_data.question: A 51-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 3-week history of abnormal behavior. His wife reports he has been preoccupied with gambling at the local casino. He becomes restless and irritable when his wife attempts to restrict his gambling. Four months ago, he was diagnosed with Parkinson disease and treatment was initiated. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug that was most likely prescribed for this patient?

options.C: Selective inhibition of monoamine oxidase B

model_response:
The patient was most likely prescribed levodopa, which is a precursor of dopamine. Levodopa is metabolized by two enzymes, DOPA decarboxylase and catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) to 3-methoxy-4-hydroxy-L-phenylalanine (3-OMD) and homovanillic acid. DOPA decarboxylase is present in the brain and peripheral tissues. COMT is present in peripheral tissues and the brain. DOPA decarboxylase inhibitors (carbidopa and benserazide) are often used in conjunction with levodopa to increase the amount of levodopa that crosses the blood-brain barrier and is available to be metabolized by DOPA decarboxylase to 3-OMD. DOPA decarboxylase inhibitors do not penetrate the blood-brain barrier. Direct activation of dopamine receptors (option B) is not a mechanism of action of any anti-Parkinson medications. Selective inhibition of monoamine oxidase B (option C) is the mechanism of action of selegiline.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
A female partner in marriage.
Record and study of past events.
Troublesome or disruptive behavioral displays.
A female partner in marriage.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
An activity distinguished primarily by an element of risk in trying to obtain a desired goal, e.g., playing a game of chance for money.

A state of restlessness associated with unpleasant feelings of irritability and tension. Causes include pain, stress, fever, alcohol and nicotine withdrawal, cocaine and hallucinogenic drugs use, depression, bipolar disorders, and schizophrenia.
Abnormal or excessive excitability with easily triggered anger, annoyance, or impatience.
A female partner in marriage.
Anything that limits; a limitation.
An activity distinguished primarily by an element of risk in trying to obtain a desired goal, e.g., playing a game of chance for money.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.

A progressive, degenerative neurologic disease characterized by a TREMOR that is maximal at rest, retropulsion (i.e. a tendency to fall backwards), rigidity, stooped posture, slowness of voluntary movements, and a masklike facial expression. Pathologic features include loss of melanin containing neurons in the substantia nigra and other pigmented nuclei of the brainstem. LEWY BODIES are present in the substantia nigra and locus coeruleus but may also be found in a related condition (LEWY BODY DISEASE, DIFFUSE) characterized by dementia in combination with varying degrees of parkinsonism. (Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p1059, pp1067-75)

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
The means by which an effect is obtained.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
